text: FCIC 24010

text: DEFINITIONS
label: BODY

text: County actuarial structure. A record of different coverage and/or rates with
label: BODY

text: respective identification.
label: BODY

text: Farming operation.  One or more persons who participate in establishing a yield
label: BODY

text: history.  Corporations, partnerships, and family operations are included under
label: BODY

text: this title.
label: BODY

text: Flood frequency.  The number of times flooding occurs over a period of years.
label: BODY

text: Flood severity.  The degree of damage or loss caused by flooding over a period
label: BODY

text: of a year or years.
label: BODY

text: High-risk land.  Acreage with identifiable physical limitations to crop production
label: BODY

text: that may increase the potential frequency and/or severity of loss; or expose a
label: BODY

text: planted or intended crop to perils not generally encountered by most insureds.
label: BODY

text: Such acreage may consist of flood plains, poorly drained areas, high sand
label: BODY

text: content soils, high aluminum toxicity soils, high sodium content soils, high alkali
label: BODY

text: soils, peat soils, soils with high or low pH, soils that are highly erodible, etc.
label: BODY

text: Homogeneous yield area.  Defined portions of a county or state with similar
label: BODY

text: crop yield or yield capabilities.
label: BODY

text: Individual Determined Yield.  A yield determined by the RMA Regional Office
label: BODY

text: (RO) used to complete a four-year base period when less than four years of
label: BODY

text: actual production history are provided.
label: BODY

text: Nonactual yield.  Any yield other than an actual yield that is used for the
label: BODY

text: purpose of determining insurance coverage.  Such yields include transitional,
label: BODY

text: adjusted transitional, assigned APH yields, yield substitutions, etc.
label: BODY

text: Unclassified/Unrated Land.  Acreage within a county without published
label: BODY

text: coverage and/or rates.
label: BODY

text: FCIC 24010
label: BODY

text: COVERAGE DETERMINATION See [Exhibit 4]
label: BODY

text: Adjusting Transitional Yields For High-Risk Land
label: BODY

text: To reduce the frequency of excessive indemnities in high-risk areas, RMA may
label: BODY

text: adjust transitional yields (T-Yields) by using T-Yield Map Areas or other actuarial
label: BODY

text: document, to more accurately reflect an average yield for the area.  The T-Yields
label: BODY

text: in the database are also subject to change.  Refer to the Crop Insurance
label: BODY

text: Handbook (CIH) for more information on T-Yields.
label: BODY

text: Identify areas of high-risk land on the FCI-33, FCI-33 Legal Descriptor
label: BODY

text: Document or FCI-33 Supplement. Use Natural Resource Conservation
label: BODY

text: Service (NRCS) soils surveys, climatological data, insurance experience,
label: BODY

text: RMA RO site inspections, and local resource personnel to determine the
label: BODY

text: presence of high-risk land.
label: BODY

text: Determine the adjusted “T- Yield” for a high-risk area:
label: BODY

text: (2)(a) Calculation.  Divide the weighted average yield potential of
label: BODY

text: predominant soil-mapping units in the high-risk area (High-Risk
label: BODY

text: Yield [HRY]), by the weighted average yield for the predominant
label: BODY

text: soils of the cropland in the entire county (County Average Yield
label: BODY

text: [CAY]), excluding any high-risk land.  HRY/CAY = Yield Factor (F).
label: BODY

text: (2)(b) Determine the County Transitional Yield (T-Yield by
label: BODY

text: practice/type/map area) from the county actuarial documents.
label: BODY

text: Multiply the County T-Yield by Yield Factor (F) to obtain the
label: BODY

text: adjusted T-Yield for the high-risk area.  See [Exhibit 1].
label: BODY

text: Determine the adjusted T-Yield for flood prone/excess moisture areas:
label: BODY

text: Yields published by NRCS do not account for probable losses due to
label: BODY

text: recurring problems with flooding and excess moisture; the following can
label: BODY

text: be used to determine an adjusted T-Yield:
label: BODY

text: (3)(a) Determine the County T-Yield (by practice/type/map area) from
label: BODY

text: the county actuarial documents.
label: BODY

text: (3)(b) Compute the flood/excess moisture frequency.  Subtract the
label: BODY

text: flood/excess moisture frequency from 1.00.  Multiply the result
label: BODY

text: times the County T-Yield.  This will be the adjusted T-Yield for the
label: BODY

text: flood-prone/excess moisture land.
label: BODY

text: Soils with no published yields (contact NRCS for updated or
label: BODY

text: unpublished lists) may be ranked by using methods such as yield
label: BODY

text: potential versus available water, comparability with other similar soils,
label: BODY

text: adjustments for slope, salinity, etc., and interactions of these
label: BODY

text: characteristics. Other sources of supporting information include
label: BODY

text: climatological data, actual yield history, geographic information system
label: BODY

text: mapping, university personnel and reports, NRCS and FSA personnel.
label: BODY

text: NOTE:  Determination of adjusted T-Yields for high-risk land should be
label: BODY

text: thoroughly documented and retained in the county work folder.
label: BODY

text: FCIC 24010
label: BODY

text: Master Yields
label: BODY

text: Approving County Crop Programs For Master Yields
label: BODY

text: Use the following standards to recommend county crop programs for
label: BODY

text: master yields:
label: BODY

text: (1)(a) Agronomic practices generally preclude the accumulation of a
label: BODY

text: complete four years of production history in a ten-year calendar
label: BODY

text: period for a unit.
label: BODY

text: (1)(b) Unbiased third-party evidence of planted acreage and harvested
label: BODY

text: production (supporting evidence) is available through a processor
label: BODY

text: or the insured.
label: BODY

text: (1)(c) The occurrence of a large number of policies for the crop and
label: BODY

text: predominance of crop share (vs. cash rent/ownership) may cause
label: BODY

text: administrative problems with an operator entity master yield,
label: BODY

text: because sharing landowners may be insured with a different
label: BODY

text: company.  NOTE:  Added land procedures for standard APH will
label: BODY

text: not apply to a crop in a county eligible for master yields.  If the
label: BODY

text: crop has not been produced for four years or more, producers
label: BODY

text: would not be eligible for master yields and will be limited to
label: BODY

text: variable or 100% T-Yields.
label: BODY

text: (1)(d) Master yields are applicable on a county crop program basis.
label: BODY

text: Different Master yields may be established for areas with similar
label: BODY

text: growing conditions. This is referred to as the master yield
label: BODY

text: homogenous area.
label: BODY

text: (1)(e) Submit recommended changes to the Master Yield List in Exhibit
label: BODY

text: 7 of the CIH by crop and state or by county crop program to the
label: BODY

text: Product Development Division no later than COB on the first of
label: BODY

text: March each calendar year.
label: BODY

text: Determining Homogeneous Master Yield Areas
label: BODY

text: (2)(a)  Considerations when determining a homogeneous master yield
label: BODY

text: area include:
label: BODY

text: 1 Soil type and yield potential;
label: BODY

text: 2 Rainfall and climatic conditions;
label: BODY

text: 3 Farming practices and management;
label: BODY

text: 4 Loss experience;
label: BODY

text: 5 Actuarial maps; and
label: BODY

text: 6 Farm Serial Numbers (FSN) or legal descriptions.
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2003
label: BODY

text: FCIC 24010
label: BODY

text: Hard-Copy Evidence For Master Yields
label: BODY

text: For cases where the RMA RO determines the approved APH yield, the
label: BODY

text: RMA RO may require hard-copy evidence of production when reported
label: BODY

text: yields do not appear reasonable.
label: BODY

text: (3)(a) Reasonable means: The reported yield is greater than the result
label: BODY

text: of multiplying the applicable lower level yield edit factor for annual
label: BODY

text: crops contained in the Data Acceptance System (DAS) manual
label: BODY

text: times the transitional yield for the practice/type for the county or
label: BODY

text: area within a county.
label: BODY

text: (3)(b) Send a letter to the Insurance Provider (IP) describing the
label: BODY

text: required hard-copy evidence.  Remind the company/agent that
label: BODY

text: RMA RO will assign a yield if the required evidence is not returned
label: BODY

text: within 20 calendar days from the date of notification from the RMA
label: BODY

text: RO.
label: BODY

text: Transfer Of APH Yield History For Master Yields
label: BODY

text: (4)(a) In some cases, an insured with a master yield may expand the
label: BODY

text: farming operation across a county or state line or form a new
label: BODY

text: entity.  When this occurs, the published Transitional Yield may not
label: BODY

text: be appropriate.  The RMA RO may determine a yield (F Yield
label: BODY

text: Descriptor) to be used in place of the published Transitional Yield
label: BODY

text: until four years of production history can be accumulated.  Upon
label: BODY

text: receipt of a timely filed Request For Actuarial Change (as defined
label: BODY

text: in the CIH), the RMA RO may consider determining a yield for the
label: BODY

text: following cases:
label: BODY

text: 1 Producers who have a master yield in a county and expand
label: BODY

text: their operation into an adjacent county that has similar yield
label: BODY

text: expectations.
label: BODY

text: 2 Individuals who participate in the creation of a master yield
label: BODY

text: credited to another person (New Entity) must have participated
label: BODY

text: in management of the crop for at least four years.  In addition,
label: BODY

text: the RMA RO must determine that a reasonable expectation of
label: BODY

text: similar production from this new entity exists in order to issue
label: BODY

text: an RO Determined Yield.  If the entity change qualifies for
label: BODY

text: successor-in-interest, a total transfer of the database would be
label: BODY

text: used.  Refer to Section 4 in the CIH.
label: BODY

text: (4)(b) RMA RO Determined Yields
label: BODY

text: 1 MAP AREAS:  This procedure may apply to counties that have
label: BODY

text: map areas if the Transitional Yield in the map area in the
label: BODY

text: county expanded into is within 15 percent of the Transitional
label: BODY

text: Yield in the map area of the existing county.  The RO
label: BODY

text: Determined Yield will be reduced by the ratio of the
label: BODY

text: Transitional Yields, but will not be increased above the actual
label: BODY

text: yields.  No RO Determined Yields are authorized between
label: BODY

text: map areas within a county.
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2003
label: BODY

text: FCIC 24010
label: BODY

text: 2 RO’s may determine and issue a reasonable yield to be used
label: BODY

text: in place of the Transitional Yield until four years of actual
label: BODY

text: yields can be accumulated.  Reasonable yields may be
label: BODY

text: determined by:
label: BODY

text: a Using NRCS soil survey yields by soil-mapping unit to
label: BODY

text: establish relationships between acreage.
label: BODY

text: b Indexing yields using the ratio of Transitional Yields or
label: BODY

text: processor averages between Transitional Yield areas,
label: BODY

text: types, practices, or varieties.  The RO Determined Yield
label: BODY

text: will not exceed the actual yields obtained by the original
label: BODY

text: entity or adjacent county.
label: BODY

text: 3 The RMA RO will establish the RO Determined Yield and
label: BODY

text: issue it in a letter to the company instructing them to use the
label: BODY

text: yield in the master yield Database(s) with an “F” descriptor and
label: BODY

text: to keep the letter in the producer’s file until four years of actual
label: BODY

text: history is accumulated on the master yield(s).

text: Perennial Crop Underwriting Guidelines
label: BODY

text: Submit proposed guidelines or updates to existing guidelines to the Product
label: BODY

text: Development Division for approval.  Existing guidelines will apply unless changes
label: BODY

text: are submitted for approval prior to the yield determination process for the crop
label: BODY

text: year.
label: BODY

text: Each RMA RO will establish underwriting guidelines to determine yield
label: BODY

text: adjustments when needed.  Consider the following criteria when
label: BODY

text: developing these guidelines:
label: BODY

text: (1)(a) The use of inspection reports which indicate the condition of the
label: BODY

text: crop, cultural practices, level of management, etc.
label: BODY

text: (1)(b) The use of insured's yield history.
label: BODY

text: (1)(c) History of previous insureds.
label: BODY

text: (1)(d) Variations in base yield for each crop within states and between
label: BODY

text: states.
label: BODY

text: (1)(e) Current growth stage.
label: BODY

text: (1)(f) Orchard density and tree spacing.
label: BODY

text: (1)(g) Tree/vine/bush variety (cultivar) by block or unit.
label: BODY

text: (1)(h) Degree of carryover damage (disease, freeze, etc.).
label: BODY

text: Outside sources of underwriting information such as university
label: BODY

text: extension specialists, etc.
label: BODY

text: Yield Limitations and Adjustments

text: HIGH RISK LAND RATE CLASSIFICATION
label: H4

text: Flood.  Each river and its flood plain represent complex interaction between
label: BODY

text: hydrology, topography, crop physiology, weather, soils, and the effects of human
label: BODY

text: intervention, see [Exhibit 3].
label: BODY

text: Flood is a random predictable peril affecting identifiable locations and
label: BODY

text: representing a definable risk that is in addition to the standard insurance risk for
label: BODY

text: the crop and county.  (Recurrent frequency of the event within a locality is
label: BODY

text: observable and measurable.)  These unique characteristics dictate a separate
label: BODY

text: accounting for the risk within an actuarial structure of an insurance product.  This
label: BODY

text: segregation of risk is typical for all crop, property, and personal liability products
label: BODY

text: offering flood insurance.
label: BODY

text: Rating Flood Prone Land.
label: BODY

text: (1)(a) Rate flood prone land based on the extent, frequency, and
label: BODY

text: severity of loss.  The determined premium rate (additive,
label: BODY

text: multiplicative, or fixed) that corresponds with a classification
label: BODY

text: assignment on the FCI-33 will be listed on the FCI-35, Coverage
label: BODY

text: and Rates table.  Premium rates or rate area classifications may
label: BODY

text: also be identified on the FCI-33 Legal Descriptor or FCI-33.  More
label: BODY

text: than one rated area may be identified on these actuarial
label: BODY

text: documents if the county has multiple river, streams, or
label: BODY

text: watersheds; if crops are grown between the river and a levee, or
label: BODY

text: the risk of flood varies within the same location (e.g., changes in
label: BODY

text: elevation).
label: BODY

text: (2)(b) Rating for flood requires consideration of the crop, the extent of
label: BODY

text: potential flooding, flood severity, and frequency of occurrence.
label: BODY

text: Determine the minimum flood stage or elevation that will be used
label: BODY

text: to determine flood frequency.  A premium rate may be calculated
label: BODY

text: for an area using river gage stations along the river or from a
label: BODY

text: comparable watershed.  Readings should be obtained for at least
label: BODY

text: the most recent 20-year period that data are available.
label: BODY

text: Determining extent, frequency, and severity.
label: BODY

text: (2)(a) Isolating the extent of flood risk is the process of identifying land
label: BODY

text: directly and indirectly affected by flooding.  A direct impact would
label: BODY

text: be on unprotected land adjacent to the river.  Resulting damage
label: BODY

text: would be immediate and obvious.  An indirect impact may be on
label: BODY

text: acreage behind a levee that is vulnerable to seepage,
label: BODY

text: overtopping, levee breach, high water table, or poor drainage.
label: BODY

text: The extent of potential flooding is influenced by elevation, flood
label: BODY

text: magnitude, topography, presence and amount of natural
label: BODY

text: vegetation during the year, watershed size, flood control
label: BODY

text: measures, and artificial drainage.  Flood zone maps produced by
label: BODY

text: other governmental entities, topography maps, soil surveys, direct
label: BODY

text: physical observation, aerial photography, etc., may be used to
label: BODY

text: determine the extent of flood risk.  Use the FCI-33 to show
label: BODY

text: determined high-risk area boundaries.
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2003
label: BODY

text: FCIC 24010
label: BODY

text: (2)(b) Determining frequency consists of tabulating how often, when,
label: BODY

text: and the duration of flooding.  There are many possible flood
label: BODY

text: magnitudes; hence, many possible elevations affected within a
label: BODY

text: flood plain.  Duration and timing also have significant influence.
label: BODY

text: Short duration flooding late in the growing season may produce
label: BODY

text: negligible damage to a particular crop.  The same type of flood
label: BODY

text: experienced during mid-season may cause total loss.  The
label: BODY

text: opposite results may be produced when a different crop is
label: BODY

text: planted.
label: BODY

text: 1 Determining the frequency and severity of crop loss from a
label: BODY

text: historical flood depends on gaining an idea of:
label: BODY

text: a When it occurred during the year.
label: BODY

text: b The depth of the water.
label: BODY

text: The size of the area affected.
label: BODY

text: d How fast the water moved.
label: BODY

text: e How quickly the water receded.
label: BODY

text: 2 In addition to these historical observations, unique
label: BODY

text: characteristics of each crop and the applicable insurance
label: BODY

text: program must be considered:
label: BODY

text: a When the crop is normally planted.
label: BODY

text: b How high the crop grows.
label: BODY

text: At what point(s) during the growing season is the crop
label: BODY

text: more or less susceptible to flood damage.
label: BODY

text: d What features of the insurance product mitigate or
label: BODY

text: enhance the potential for indemnification.
label: BODY

text: Example considerations:
label: BODY

text: A major flood in the Midwest in early March has no
label: BODY

text: effect on the probability or severity of a corn loss
label: BODY

text: because the crop is not normally planted.
label: BODY

text: The effects of a slow moving, shallow flood that
label: BODY

text: recedes reasonably quickly during early September
label: BODY

text: will be negligible effects on corn, but catastrophic to
label: BODY

text: soybeans.
label: BODY

text: A late April flood that drains away quickly may produce
label: BODY

text: a corn replanting payment, but is not likely to result in a
label: BODY

text: total loss unless soil type drainage limitations or
label: BODY

text: continued rainfall prevent replanting the crop.
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2003
label: BODY

text: FCIC 24010
label: BODY

text: (2)(c) Determining loss severity involves identifying the percentage of
label: BODY

text: crop loss associated with each historical flood when data are
label: BODY

text: available.  Flood is usually catastrophic to a growing plant.
label: BODY

text: It does not gradually reduce a plant's ability to produce (such as
label: BODY

text: drought). The plant is most often simply eliminated.  However,
label: BODY

text: consideration to overall loss within an area must be given when
label: BODY

text: evaluating each event.  For example, an early season flood may
label: BODY

text: result in replanting or delayed planting of the crop.  Final yields
label: BODY

text: may be unaffected or reduced.  A crop planted later than normal
label: BODY

text: due to flooding is younger and more vulnerable to stress from
label: BODY

text: drier summer conditions than a timely planted crop.  The resulting
label: BODY

text: cause of loss may be drought although the initial contributing
label: BODY

text: factor was flood.
label: BODY

text: Develop a flood severity scale for each crop.  Apply the scale
label: BODY

text: whenever the river exceeds flood stage or a point where crop
label: BODY

text: damage may occur.  This flood severity scale should
label: BODY

text: account for the time of the flood and the expected yield loss.
label: BODY

text: Early season flooding causes delayed planting or replanting of the
label: BODY

text: crop without severely limiting crop potential.  While floods
label: BODY

text: occurring near the final planting dates and later are often
label: BODY

text: catastrophic.  An example of a severity table ranking the
label: BODY

text: significance of each historical event may look like the following:

text: Evaluating flood gage peak flow discharge verses daily flow
label: BODY

text: discharge rates.
label: BODY

text: (3)(a) When evaluating peak and daily flow discharges, a difference will
label: BODY

text: be seen between the cubic flow amounts recorded in each data
label: BODY

text: set.  A block of data may look like this:
label: BODY

text: Date             Peak Flow Discharge           Daily Flow Discharge
label: BODY

text: (3)(b) The peak flow discharge is the instantaneous discharge for the
label: BODY

text: highest gage height recorded for that day (or period).  Gage height
label: BODY

text: is measured usually every 15 minutes, although some programs
label: BODY

text: have a variable time recording of gage height.  The highest gage
label: BODY

text: height reached is used to compute the peak discharge.
label: BODY

text: (3)(c) The daily flow discharge is the average sum of the discharges
label: BODY

text: obtained from the daily gage height readings.  This is why the
label: BODY

text: peak flow is higher than the average flow.
label: BODY

text: (3)(d) These differences have several ramifications on flood rating.
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2003

text: FCIC 24010
label: BODY

text: 1 When performing flood event analysis, recognize that a daily
label: BODY

text: flow discharge has affected more or less of the flood plain on
label: BODY

text: that day than the daily average or mean alone.
label: BODY

text: 2 A large variation between peak and daily average flow may
label: BODY

text: suggest:
label: BODY

text: a Faster moving water and quicker plant destruction.
label: BODY

text: b Presence and effect from flood abatement measures.
label: BODY

text: Possible water release or diversion from man-made flood
label: BODY

text: control structures.
label: BODY

text: d Flood damage between levees and the river may be more
label: BODY

text: immediate and more severe than on an unprotected river.

label: BODY

text: Climatic Conditions and Microclimates
label: BODY

text: The climatic conditions, length of growing season, Growing Degree Days
label: BODY

text: (GDD), risk of frost and/or freeze are so common in the area or micro
label: BODY

text: climate that the success in growing the crop (or lack of data) may be
label: BODY

text: infrequent and it cannot be determined that the crop is adapted to the
label: BODY

text: area.  Frost and freeze probabilities (temperature, frequency, and
label: BODY

text: duration) associated with the crop (annual or
label: BODY

text: perennial)/type/variety/growth stage, geographic location, and topography
label: BODY

text: are important considerations when it comes to determinations of
label: BODY

text: insurance coverage and appropriate rates (premium) that are acceptable
label: BODY

text: to the insured and insurer.  The below listed items identify possible
label: BODY

text: considerations when making frost and freeze rating determinations.   See
label: BODY

text: also [6 Unclassified/Unrated Land].
label: BODY

text: The county contains numerous microclimates or areas where the growing
label: BODY

text: season is limited or inadequate to produce the crop/type.
label: BODY

text: Frost and /or freeze. Crop losses increase dramatically as the
label: BODY

text: temperature falls below the critical temperature sometimes defined as the
label: BODY

text: temperature at which a 10% loss in production is expected.  As an
label: BODY

text: example the difference between a light 10 percent killing frost and a
label: BODY

text: disastrous 90% kill may be 3 degrees Fahrenheit.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: passage; indeed radiational cooling may bring further surface cooling to

text: General High Risk Rate Calculations.
label: BODY

text: The basic formula for rating a high-risk peril such as flood is:
label: BODY

text: F x S = Peril Base Premium Rate Add-on
label: BODY

text: Where:
label: BODY

text: F = Frequency of Loss Occurrence Over Time
label: BODY

text: S = Severity of Loss
label: BODY

text: A rate determination for measurable risk within defined boundaries
label: BODY

text: may involve the use of two modified forms of this basic rate formula
label: BODY

text: depending on what type of rating (Worst Case Rating verses Class
label: BODY

text: Average Rating) best fits the characteristics of the risk and its location.
label: BODY

text: UNCLASSIFIED/UNRATED LAND
label: BODY

text: Distribution of production guarantees is accomplished by classifying the
label: BODY

text: county coverage acreage and risk into homogeneous groups (areas) according
label: BODY

text: to productivity based on soil capabilities, actual yields and other factors or
label: BODY

text: combination of factors available to the Risk Management Specialist that best
label: BODY

text: measures actual or relative land productivity.
label: BODY

text: Rates are set according to risk of loss in identified areas of the county with the
label: BODY

text: objective of collecting sufficient premiums to pay indemnities and accumulate a
label: BODY

text: reserve over time.  See also [5C High Risk Land Rate Classification/Climatic
label: BODY

text: Conditions and Microclimates].
label: BODY

text: Reasons for identifying an area(s) within a county as unclassified/unrated
label: BODY

text: Coverage will not be provided for areas not considered suitable for
label: BODY

text: production of the commodity being insured.
label: BODY

text: (1)(a) Noncropland (i.e., NRCS Class VIII rating or severe limitations
label: BODY

text: make them unsuitable for production of the insured crops, parks,
label: BODY

text: military reservations, etc) where it is felt they need to be identified.
label: BODY

text: (1)(b) Land that is uninsurable or has uninsurable causes of loss based
label: BODY

text: on the policy (i.e., subject to backup/contained water/flood
label: BODY

text: easements, stripmines, reclaimed land, etc.).
label: BODY

text: (1)(c) Classes of soils identified by NRCS whose severe limitations
label: BODY

text: make them unsuitable for crop production.
label: BODY

text: Soils and/or climate are not considered suitable for production of the
label: BODY

text: commodity being insured due to factors such as productivity, moisture
label: BODY

text: availability, growing season restrictions.
label: BODY

text: (2)(a) The risk of growing the insured crop in this area is so great and/or
label: BODY

text: uncertain that a sound insurance program cannot be operated.
label: BODY

text: (2)(b) The land and/or risk factors in question have so much variation
label: BODY

text: within these areas that rating on an area basis is not possible.
label: BODY

text: The risks are so “variable” that the crop cannot be pre-rated on a
label: BODY

text: map and must be individually rated by Written Agreement, FCI-33
label: BODY

text: Legal Descriptor or FCI-33 Supplement.
label: BODY

text: (2)(c) Land along major rivers and islands that are farmed only during
label: BODY

text: year’s when water levels are low.
label: BODY

text: (2)(d) Cropland that has risks so “frequent and/or severe” that actuarially
label: BODY

text: sound rates cannot be determined.
label: BODY

text: (2)(e) Areas with no history of producing the crop to show adaptability,
label: BODY

text: such as perennials in a county with numerous microclimates.
label: BODY

text: (2)(f) Deep, excessively drained, very rapidly permeable soils.
label: BODY

text: (2)(g) Other factors such as disease problems.

text: EXHIBIT 3
label: BODY

text: Flood Plain Characteristics And Rating Implications
label: BODY

text: Type 1
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: The profile is typical of smaller streams at the beginning of watersheds.  It may also
label: BODY

text: describe larger rivers in mountainous areas depending on the type of existing parent
label: BODY

text: material.  Flood plain development and agricultural use are minimal.  Slopes, lack of
label: BODY

text: tillable land, low productivity are limitations.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications included with surrounding insurable land:
label: BODY

text: There are minimal rating implications due to the absence of insurable land.  These
label: BODY

text: profiles are usually assigned standard class rates.  Or, they may be included with
label: BODY

text: exceptional rate classifications assigned to larger associated flood plains.
label: BODY

text: Type 2
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: Type 1 profiles generally evolve into Type 2 profiles.  Slope of the flood plain is steep (B
label: BODY

text: and C slopes).  A more or less constant slope exists between flood plain boundaries and
label: BODY

text: the river.  Acreage becomes tillable depending on the suitability of soil types although
label: BODY

text: much remains in woodland or pasture.  There are relatively few fields with uniform land
label: BODY

text: elevations.  Floodwater drainage is usually rapid.  However, water speed will produce
label: BODY

text: immediate damage by scouring or laying the crop down.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications:
label: BODY

text: The uniformity of profile slope toward the river suggests class average rating is
label: BODY

text: appropriate.
label: BODY

text: Type 1
label: BODY

text: Type 2
label: BODY

text: T y p e  2
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2003
label: BODY

text: FCIC 24010
label: BODY

text: Type 3
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: The flood plain has fully developed and is generally surrounded by rolling land.  Soil
label: BODY

text: types are often derived from a mixture of alluvial and colluvial deposits.  Very little or no
label: BODY

text: slope exists next to the river.  There is very little or no observable development of
label: BODY

text: primary and secondary flood plains.  Slope increases dramatically at the flood plain
label: BODY

text: boundary.  This marked elevation increase is commonly referred to as a bluff line.
label: BODY

text: Floodwater speed is slower.  However, drainage away from the flood plain is also
label: BODY

text: slower.  Crop damage from extended submersion instead of water speed is typical.
label: BODY

text: Damage from high water tables and poor internal soil drainage become more common.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications:
label: BODY

text: Worst case rating is commonly used.  Class average rating might be used depending on
label: BODY

text: the degree of slope (more) and severity of historical discharge volume (less) in the
label: BODY

text: primary flood zone.
label: BODY

text: Type 4
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: This profile exists in two forms.  It may be part of a Type 3 profile in larger flood plains
label: BODY

text: along major rivers or it may be common in regions with predominately flat terrain such as
label: BODY

text: the Midwest.  There is very little variation in slope.  No distinction of variable flood risk
label: BODY

text: within the profile can reasonably be made.  On a flat terrain, that would normally be a
label: BODY

text: small creek or river may produce floods of impressive proportions even after moderate
label: BODY

text: rainfall because extent is not confined by land elevation.  Smaller Type 4 profiles are
label: BODY

text: often more frequently flooded than similar profiles along major rivers due to the greater
label: BODY

text: influence of local weather.  Flood timing and its variable relationship to crop damage
label: BODY

text: become important rating considerations.  The effects of Type 4 profile flooding a crop
label: BODY

text: along major rivers is almost always catastrophic regardless of timing during the growing
label: BODY

text: season.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications:
label: BODY

text: Worst case rating is used.
label: BODY

text: Type 3
label: BODY

text: T y p e  3
label: BODY

text: Type 4
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2003
label: BODY

text: FCIC 24010
label: BODY

text: Type 5
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: A Type 5 profile is a Type 4 profile with some minimal flood abatement measures.
label: BODY

text: These measures may include piled dirt field boundaries, non-Corps specification levees,
label: BODY

text: and passive drainage ditches.  Flood abatement measures may have anywhere from no
label: BODY

text: effect on flood frequency to legitimate flood prevention depending on many other land
label: BODY

text: characteristics.  Abatement measures may also work to increase potential crop damage
label: BODY

text: from excessive moisture and poor drainage.  Drainage of water runoff from adjacent
label: BODY

text: uplands or direct flooding may become increasingly difficult.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications:
label: BODY

text: Rating may become dependent on the quality of flood abatement measures.  The entire
label: BODY

text: flood plain may be worst case rated, only that acreage between flood abatement
label: BODY

text: measures and the river may be worst case rated.  Or, a combination of worst case and
label: BODY

text: class average rating may be appropriate.
label: BODY

text: Type 6
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: This profile may be found along older river channels that have changed course over
label: BODY

text: time.  Land elevation for some portions of the flood plain is at or even below
label: BODY

text: the current river channel.  When flooding occurs, lower elevations away from the
label: BODY

text: river are inundated and unable to drain back into the river as water recedes.
label: BODY

text: Flood damage away from the river may actually be more severe than on land adjacent to
label: BODY

text: the river.  Direct overflow and normal runoff from surrounding land may create severe
label: BODY

text: drainage limitations.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications:
label: BODY

text: Worst case rating is applicable.  There may be unusual situations where worst case
label: BODY

text: rating applies to depressional areas while class average or standard rating is reasonable
label: BODY

text: for land closer to the river.
label: BODY

text: Type 5
label: BODY

text: T y p e  6
label: BODY

text: Type 6
label: BODY

text: T y p e  6
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2003
label: BODY

text: FCIC 24010
label: BODY

text: Type 7
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: This irregular profile is usually produced by variation of parent material within the flood
label: BODY

text: plain.  Parent materials subject to differing rates of erosion and older colluvial or glacial
label: BODY

text: deposits contribute to the ‘washboard’ appearance of this profile.  Potential flood
label: BODY

text: damage on associated farmland is highly variable.  There may be knolls in the flood
label: BODY

text: plain that do not flood aside depressional areas similar to a Type 6 profile.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications:
label: BODY

text: Appropriate rating methods are dependent on the distribution and size of farmed fields
label: BODY

text: within the flood plain.  If only those areas not subject to flood are farmed, standard rating
label: BODY

text: may be used.  If fields are large with continuous mono-cropping across the flood plain,
label: BODY

text: class average rating may be used.  If only small fields in lower areas are farmed, worst
label: BODY

text: case rating is used.
label: BODY

text: Type 8
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: A Type 8 profile is similar to a Type 4 profile.  The difference is a Type 4 profile is
label: BODY

text: beginning to show development of primary and secondary flood plains.  It is often not
label: BODY

text: possible to physically distinguish between them for rating purposes.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications:
label: BODY

text: Average class or worst case may be appropriate depending on the distribution and slope
label: BODY

text: of land in each flood plain.
label: BODY

text: Type 7
label: BODY

text: T y p e  6

text: Type 9
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: Type 9 profiles have extensive primary and secondary flood plain development.
label: BODY

text: It is possible to separate land for rating purposes.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications:
label: BODY

text: Generally, average class rating is applied to secondary flood plains due to lower risk and
label: BODY

text: increasing slope.  Worst case is appropriate for primary flood plains depending on the
label: BODY

text: extent and quality of flood control structures.
label: BODY

text: Type 10
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: A Type 10 profile may have characteristics similar to any other type of flood plain.  The
label: BODY

text: difference is presence of a substantial flood control structure on one side of the flood
label: BODY

text: plain.  In this case, the levee may be a Corps Specification levee that is privately owned.
label: BODY

text: Existence of the structure may decrease risk behind the levee; however, severity of
label: BODY

text: flooding on the river side of the structure is general increased.  This is because
label: BODY

text: constriction of the flood plain forces water to move faster and spread out further on the
label: BODY

text: opposite side of the river.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications:
label: BODY

text: Land behind the levee may be assigned standard or average class ratings depending on
label: BODY

text: the quality of the levee, seep potential, susceptibility of soil types to excessive moisture
label: BODY

text: damage, and drainage limitations.  Worst case rating is generally applicable to land
label: BODY

text: between the river and the levee and land on the opposite side of the river.
label: BODY

text: Type 11
label: BODY

text: Characteristics:
label: BODY

text: This profile is characteristic of the largest rivers.  Corps Specification or better
label: BODY

text: levees on each side of the river define the flood plain.  Construction of the levees
label: BODY

text: is substantial and failure is not expected even under severe conditions.
label: BODY

text: Breaching does occur although not generally more often than every twenty-five to
label: BODY

text: fifty years.
label: BODY

text: Rating Implications:
label: BODY

text: Land behind the levee may be assigned standard or average class ratings
label: BODY

text: depending on the quality of the levee, seep potential, susceptibility of soil types
label: BODY

text: to excessive moisture damage, and drainage limitations.  Worst case rating is
label: BODY

text: applicable to land between the river and the levees.
label: BODY

text: EXHIBIT 4
label: BODY

text: Reference To Actuarial Structures
label: BODY

text: Almost all actuarial structures in use to classify risk and assign premium rates have their basis
label: BODY

text: in the assumption that productivity and risk are related.  As productivity increases, risk and its
label: BODY

text: associated premium rate decrease.  General types of structures include:
label: BODY

text: Single risk classification:  This actuarial structure is generally established in counties with
label: BODY

text: limited crop acreage and potential risk variation among insureds.  A single class rate applies to
label: BODY

text: all insured acreage.  An example might be an apple program in a predominately flat county with
label: BODY

text: 100 potential acres.  A low number of insureds and a lack of evident risk variation suggest a
label: BODY

text: county-wide rate is the most appropriate structure.
label: BODY

text: Multiple risk classifications: Continuous rating methods, and producer listing yield
label: BODY

text: classifications, farm yield groupings, soil productivity groupings, and practice-type-variety
label: BODY

text: groupings.  The basic underwriting concept of multi-class rating is to account for variable risk
label: BODY

text: exposure.  Use of multi-class structures makes it is possible to attract a better risk with lower
label: BODY

text: premiums while continuing to adequately rate for the higher risk.  If this approach is successful,
label: BODY

text: rates may be reduced thereby attracting more business.  In a county with many acres of a crop,
label: BODY

text: the relationship between risk and productivity generally holds true although other program
label: BODY

text: features or the presence of exceptional risk may work to degrade the actual relationship.  In a
label: BODY

text: county with limited crop acreage, this relationship may not exist.  Over- or under-rating of all
label: BODY

text: multiple risk classifications is possible if they are not systematically reviewed.
label: BODY

text: Exceptional or High Risk Classification:  The actuarial structure for exceptional risk is simply
label: BODY

text: an extension of single or multi-class rating.  Almost all perils and associated losses have a
label: BODY

text: random occurrence in a county.  For example, hail may damage crop production on 100 acres
label: BODY

text: in part of a county; however, future recurrence on the same location is unknown and
label: BODY

text: unpredictable. This type of random loss, which may happen at any location, is the basis of a
label: BODY

text: county average rate shared by all insurance participants.    The exceptional risk does not exhibit
label: BODY

text: random loss behavior.  Exceptional risk is the expectation of repetitious loss from one or more
label: BODY

text: perils in a definable location.  The best example of exceptional risk for crop and other lines of
label: BODY

text: property insurance is flood.  Flood occurs within the physical bounds of a flood plain.  It is a
label: BODY

text: measurable peril with historical frequency that is expected to continue into the future.  Other
label: BODY

text: perils also exhibit this tendency toward repetitious loss due to the natural limitations of certain
label: BODY

text: soils.   These characteristics such as aluminum toxicity, poor drainage, sand content, land
label: BODY

text: degradation, or high water table often mimic or exacerbate the effects of a weather related peril.
label: BODY

text: Price coverage plans (RA, CRC, IP, etc.) and Group Risk Plan coverage also have a revenue
label: BODY

text: factor that must be considered along with yield components in determining risk.
label: BODY
